review_title: So Happy To Be Part Of MMC!!
pros: Great, friendly culture. Team oriented nurses. Benefits are great in my opinion and more affordable than my last job. The pay is great! Leadership is supportive! They have a bunch of little benefits like tuition reimbursement, discount programs, health programs, professional advancement, etc.
cons: The only con I could think of is when you are new to the hospital you have to work every other weekend (instead of every 3rd which is what i was used to) & you have to rotate to nights every other month. This is the only thing I would change.

pros: Diversity, benefits, pto, work schedule
cons: Not much flexibility during the work day, call center environment

pros: Great team, great flexibility, awesome work
cons: None at this post's time.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Portland, ME
pros: Great team environment, nurses always helpful.
cons: They're mandating the covid-19 vaccine. If you don't get it, no job.

pros: Pros are you get to see every part of the hospital, experience the different jobs in the hospital. You meet nice people. The day goes by faster because you are always on the move. The boss is absolutely sweet and very flexible with her staff and their needs and choices. I get along with all my fellow coworkers in my department. I have met some wonderful people here and helped them through some of their difficulties, made friends where it counted and know I will always have a family, but there are still things that need to be worked on to make this a terrific environment.
cons:
You can’t sit when there is down time like a normal staff member and are always expected to be on the move especially when there are no jobs pending

Some staff don’t know your limitations and think you can move a sand bed with an iv pole and put stress on your body

You are so capable of so much more but because of past transporter’s mishaps your job is dumbed down so that you barely have any patient interactions except for the transport factor

You can be talked to stupidly by some nurses or doctors due to other people’s mishaps when in fact your mental and professional level is par to a professional staff member’s. You just feel like you have to bite your tongue. 

There is no advancement in this position like a CNA where you can have two to three positions. There is basically a dispatcher but that is it. 

You end up having to take patients down for procedures two feet down the hallway when the nurse is also going down and could have taken the patient themselves. Makes us feel like a luxury service instead of a necessity.

Absolutely no information on what the patient is going through and the ticket to ride will sometimes have: “No Principle Problem” so if the patient is in pain you don’t know what is wrong and can’t do anything to help them

There can be a lot of fellow transporters who don’t know your limitations and will not put in for a third person when dealing with a bariatric patient in a bed or there will be no prioritizing when an able and fit nurse is accompanying the bed and the transporters will throw in for another transporter to help with transporting the bed while the nurse just runs beside the bed like we are in a marathon. Absolutely in this case barely any prioritizing when there are a ton of jobs pending.

They keep building extra sections on the hospital and think that we should be able to accommodate their equipment needs. 

Staff on receiving ends of units who are expecting patients to be picked up or dropped off are constantly phoning our tiny dispatch office and complaining about the wait time. We are only human and can only do so much.

We had no raise in pay when they added two huge additional floors to the hospital which have increased our transport threefold

Nurses have NOT been canceling jobs when they get too “tired of waiting” for us to grab their patients and when we actually GET up there after traveling a trillion miles to get to their unit with the job they SHOULD have canceled we find out it was never canceled and we end up wasting time on a wild goose chase when we could have been helping another patient in need.

When patients are being discharged nurses won’t go into their rooms and take meds off the iv poles so we will have a whole room FULL of iv poles with meds which we can’t remove and then when they feel up to removing the meds the soiled utility rooms are too full and our clean-outs are now even more stressful

There is a lack of communication between shifts and their leads on rules and after working one year during one shift and another year in another shift I can’t tell what we should or shouldn’t be doing

Some staff think they can just shove their way into an elevator when we have a strict patient- transport per elevator rule which the whole hospital is aware of. They don’t care and when you get a stare by them at your badge like they want to clarify what your position is and who you think you are talking to it makes you feel like you are worthless

Staff won’t give clear hand offs to what mode of transportation a patient is going up on and when you get up there you have to express the whole “don’t shoot the messenger” lingo. And when you see a patient is walking around and then the staff says they have to go in their bed somewhere and could have easily gone in a stretcher you have more stress put on you because now you have to wait for another transporter. 

You are made to take CPR classes when you can’t even perform it on a patient because you can’t touch the patient or alter their physical status because during cpr you run the risk of cracking ribs

You can’t switch oxygen tanks or wear dro gowns and go into a dro room even though you were trained on it in another previous job

There are other things that I am probably missing, but transport is not appreciated enough for all that we do. We take patients to and from their procedures, discharge them and take them to the pharmacy and then wait in the cold sometimes for their cars to pick them up, we do morgue runs, we clean out the hospital of dirty equipment, we take equipment all over the hospital for deliveries, we pick up other equipment that we don’t supply and take them places, we do lab rounds every hour, at night we also do all the janitorial duties too. We deserve so much more respect and are just as valuable as nurses are. We ARE people and have dreams and opinions like nurses do.

review_title: Fun place to start, not the best pay
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Portland, ME
pros: Flexible scheduling as hospital is 24-7. Lots of moving around the office. Fast paced. Always new changes to make the admitting department better. You'll always be kept busy. (Mostly) wonderful co workers, I made some great friends here. Good place to get your foot in the door and gain knowledge and experience as this is usually entry level. Upper management seems knowledgeable and hard working. The managers I reported to are easy to talk to. Weekend, 2nd, 3rd shift differential, and call pay. Good healthcare benefits. Large facility always being upgraded. Plenty of overtime offered. Lots of moral boost. 8 weeks of training so you fully understand all aspects of this position. Trainers at Washington Ave are wonderful, smart, and very helpful. Managers are on the floor a lot and were always helping out the team.
cons: Hard to request time off due to lack of coverage. Admitting department desperately needs to be upgraded. This department does have a higher than average turn-over rate due to MaineHealth being so large that a lot of employees start here then transfer to other departments or companies. Pay could be better, it is practically minimum wage. There are annoying requirements and too-strict dress codes, it's 2017. Frequent workflow changes are hard to stay on top of.

pros: scheduling, flexibility, location, acuity, fast paced
cons: big hospital, parking is cheap but takes time from the day

review_title: Good job fresh out of school
pros: Lots of opportunities to learn, good learning environment
cons: Limited voice in your department, salary below national average

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Portland, ME
pros: MMC is one of the best hospitals I have worked at in my 30 years of nursing practice. I work here now part-time and my Director and Manager support and encourage my continued practice in the field of nursing. I have opportunities here that I have not found elsewhere.  Nurses are respected and listened to here.
cons: As with any institution, there are things that could improve.  There is more need for support for direct care staff (the outside community has become almost belligerent as a result of the focus on family satisfaction).and the stress on constant "satisfaction surveys" has ironically created less rather than more focus on the care of patients. Nurses are now working under the scrutiny not of the best practice standards but instead under the scrutiny of irate (often without cause) family. Constant visitation has decreased nurse to patient engagement and often creates a dis-connect between nurses and their patients.

review_title: Portland’s great hospital good be better, great nurses
pros: Portland is great, some units better than others
cons: Don’t pay enough, bad ratios

pros: Great Benefits.  I enjoyed my job.  I would have stayed there until I retired had it not been for the drastic changes outlined in the cons.
cons: They have taken (or in the process of taking) their whole administration area (payment posting, A/R, coding) and turn it into a micro managed nightmare.  Employees are placed in groups and asked to take lunch and breaks at the same time.  Not allowed to have personal items on their desks.  Have whiteboards with meetings each morning to go over team work which places some employees in a situation of being pointed out.  Management team brought in to make this Japanese version (Keisan) of a work environment have also brought in some of their friends and from what I have heard spouses to add more upper management positions at the expense of the very people who help pay their salary.  Warehouse environment with just tables.  Very distracting to work and no privacy.

pros: Leadership - personal - cutting edge
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Care Management Associate in Portland, ME
pros: Fantastic coworkers who really care about their patients. Decent benefits and options. Fair work/ life balance. I believe in the organization and its people as a whole.
cons: Management in my department was belittling and ignored employee concerns. Did not acknowledge requests for more responsibility or foster employee growth. Frowned upon initiative when it didn't fit into the small box they had created for one person to work within. I did not feel my contribution was valued or my intellect and capacity acknowledged, let alone respected, by management. Catty and secretive environment where employees with time under their belt skated by doing minimal work. Pay not sufficient for administrative non-management staff given the education requirements and increasing cost of living in this location.

review_title: Maine Medical Center Should Not Be The Career Choice of IT Professionals
pros: Good pay for working in Maine
cons:
Old style hierarchical management
Little trust placed in employees - no telecommuting
No bad weather days - In Maine it's dangerous to drive to work in the winter
Poor management - few managers with technical credentials (pride expressed in the fact that managers aren't technical professionals, little understanding of project management
Failure to accept input from employees - no suggestion program, no employee based quality assurance teams, ideas for improving the business must originate at the top
Treat non-healthcare professionals like second class citizens

pros: Well, it's a very nice location with NO parking, a super nice President, but if you have a complaint about your manager you will find that HR will back the executive every time and you will end up feeling like the little guy with no recourse.
cons: Nepotism abounds.  If you are not related to someone important, or in the drinking group where they talk about you when you aren't there, you won't get promoted, and you'll eventually get let go if their friends don't like you.  Management has been observed bullying employees and threatening them with loss of work.

pros: Lots of committees for nurses to join to have input about nursing practice change. Pay is competitive and you get compensated more for working night shifts or evening shifts etc... Lots of growth for nurses if you want it bad enough.
cons: Most floors rotate day/night shifts and scheduling is a nightmare. PTO is accrued and is very low and takes many years to accumulate more than 2 weeks time off. The worst thing is that you are only given 3 sick days in a rolling calendar year and you can't use your PTO for random days off during the week. They must be used for your vacation only. You get a written warning for calling out sick 4 times in a rolling calendar year, then for 5 you get a disciplinary action, and for 6 call outs you get fired. If you leave halfway through a shift, it is counted as a call out or sick day and counts against you.

review_title: Invest in Growing Your Internal Talent.
job_title: Patient Access Associate in Portland, ME
pros: Hard-working, dedicated employees, strong patient-centered culture, notable reputation, growing organization.
cons: Exceeded goals expected of me as a member of the department (Access-developed benchmarks), and after 1 year, pursued other opportunities within the organization that best fit my professional goals. Was quickly not selected for ANY internal transfer that I was qualified or over-qualified for. No email or phone correspondence - just a “While you have not been selected...” on the Application homepage. HR states MMC has no career development program or assistance for their employees who are looking to grow within MaineHealth. It’s a shame to have worked so hard while creating a strong rapport, to know that I wasn’t valued by my organization.

review_title: Good place to live and work.
pros:
Magnet status has provided a measure of respect for our nurses that was previously not so obvious.  Level I Trauma tertiary referral center for southern Maine and NH.  Overall physican/nurse relationships are collegial and respectful. Many new upgrades to the facility (parking, new OB/Gyn/NICU wing, soon to be completed ED expansion). 
The hospital sits amidst a culturally diverse, artsy city with plenty of opportunity for advanced scholarship (several universities), wonderful museums and galleries, trendy shopping, sports, nightlife and safe streets.  Our climate is quite suitable for any type of adventure depending on the season.  Great place to work and live.
cons: It's not for you if you have preference for small community-type hospitals.

pros: Largest Hospital Organization in the State.  Epic EMR across the system offering one patient one records for all hospitals and all practices.  Becoming more innovative and turning over executive leadership, bringing in new blood, new ideas, new leadership is foundational to cultural change.  Believe significant change and improvements are finally on the horizon.
cons: Significant burn out in IT resources due to Epic implementation.  Difficult culture that is not innovative or inspiring.  Endless hours of work for salaried employees.  Burnout eminent because of lack of work-life balance..  Too many contract staff in managment and leadership roles. Contract staff should be short term, project based when you don't need to retain the knowledge when the project is complete.

pros: Portland area is a fun place to live and work under the right conditions  , great local beaches
cons:
Old world IS management take nepotism to the max, real workers continue to resign, incredible stress,  burnout ongoing, contributing to a steady flow of quality worker resignations. New senior management brought in does little more than intimidate, legacy management excels at maintaining 
Status quo. Inexperiencedbig talking contractors are praised, taking advantage of minimal oversight adding little.

pros: You never get bored at Maine Med, you get to see all the complicated cases that surrounding hospitals aren't equipped to deal with.  The benefits are good and the longevity of employees speaks for itself, most people have been working there for ten years plus. I have worked with some really great people and even though its a big hospital within departments it feel like a small family where everyone takes care of each other.
cons: It's a big hospital and it's easy to get "lost" literally and figuratively.  Sometimes it feels like decisions are made without and consultation with the people who actually have to implement the changes.

pros: Salary and Health Benefits. The rank and file are acceptive of background.  Good teamwork between co-workers. Friends are supportive. Shift work is usually what is desired, and not a must.
cons: Management believe it's their way or the highway. Management will not follow regulations. Human Resources usually invisible. Co-workers who complain are targeted and harassed for upsetting the balance of private fiefdoms.  Untouchable old girl network....

review_title: Talk more and do less and strive for mediocre executive and senior leadership.
job_title: Quality Project Manager in Portland, ME
pros: The staff that has direct patient care is top notch and truly advocates for the patients. I've worked for a highly regarded Boston area hospital and would choose MMC's staff in a heart beat.
cons: Executive and senior leadership have a vision but no real understanding how to operationalize a plan. Major disconnect with the front line staff.

job_title: Information Services Technician in Portland, ME
pros:
Coworkers are typically very willing to share their knowledge. 
Cafeteria on site.
cons: Few good supervisors in the entire lot, many managers and project supervisors have no abilities to lead and have no education in IT. Old, Outdated technology and processes at least 20 years behind in some respects. Communication and cooperation between departments is non existent. XP systems still operational in many locations!! Contractors and newer staff will take the fall for incompetent and cowardly leadership always who are just trying to stay quiet until they retire. Contractors are treated like 3rd class citizens and can be fired for anything by anyone at any time regardless of the good work they have done.

pros: Over the past 3 years the CBO has gone from a horrible place to work to the best place in Maine and possible the country.  We have awesome leadership and empowered high performing work teams.  Our co workers are great and you become very close and the  two new leaders who arrived from away ((CT )(PC &FU) and brought a vision and some wild ideas of Lean and high performing work teams.  They were like Trump making MMC great again and the establishment resisted and resisted.  They brought in some of the best minds and leaders nationally such as ACR RR, MP, MN, JN, WP and many others.   I was a bit resistant initially as my cubical went away was put into a Kaizen with these HEI engineers came in applying math and creating programs while guiding us in process.  Over the last couple of years we have succeeded like crazy.   It's like working at google or Apple we are engaged, drive change and love, the google like open workspace.  I am speaking for HB, Cash, RI teams we all love it!  In the past nothing got done today we escalate issues and problems when necessary have tools and process agreements and most importantly WE drive change and process and have authority and we don't have consultants giving us process.  PC believes the people doing the job are the best consultants that is us!
cons: There is still some old culture holding on especially in the PB teams but it appears leadership is beginning to start the transformation work over there.

review_title: I think mmc is vary fair to us employees
pros: I work with the best people you can work with they suport me and I suport them in every way posible.
cons: I am not reconized for the extra work I do I take on other jobs that save time and money for maine med. but they don't see it when you help out other depts. other than yours.

review_title: Lack of vision and ownership from senior leadership
job_title: Mid Level Manager in Portland, ME
pros: Front line staff are world class and truly care about the patients.
cons: Disconnected leadership with a lack of strategic vision. And if they have vision they have little experience in developing and managing an operational plan. This is evident in their heavy use of consultants.

pros: Continuing education, collegial relations among employees, support for advancement. People are helpful and friendly. Pension plan offered as well as employer contributions to retirement savings plan.
cons: Size and numbers of people can be overwhelming to visitors. Focus on patient satisfaction can make it very difficult to provide quality care. We should support best practices and educate patients/families as to why their wants are not always reasonable.

review_title: World class care at a hospital with incompetent leadership.
pros: Schedule, broad patient populous, great bedside staff, autonomy, protocol driven practice, and educating.
cons: Financial imprudence has limited their ability to respect the bedside staff's talent, creating the lowest morale I have ever seen and prompting talks of a nurse's union.

pros: Good environment to learn and grow. Great benefits, decent pay. If you can stay out of the politics and focus on patient care it'll be very rewarding and challenging.
cons: Management fosters a culture of dog eat dog, you can only advance if you spout the party line. If you criticize upper management you are punished.

review_title: Complete waste of time , 6+ project managers resigned
job_title: IS Project Manager in Portland, ME
pros: Small Minority younger clinical staff management
cons:
IS is a time capsule of soviet management style. Extreme unqualified managers maintain "power" through their old boy, their focus is big talk,not hospital success.  
Honest empolyees are punished and driven away, nepotism, deficient management practices are the norm, google Forbes and IT Healthcare magizines for the Maine Med Epic 
cost overruns. IS management hired unqualified consultants also contributing to the projects costs and failures.

job_title: Insurance Follow Up Representative in Scarborough, ME
pros: The flex time is the biggest perk for me. Direct managers genuinely appreciate my work and input.
cons: The new career ladder would be the largest perk if it would not be that there is such a large overlap between the levels. The financial motivation for taking on new challenges are lost. A team mate who is at a the lowest level could be getting the highest pay for that level which is more than the lower pay scale on a higher level.

review_title: Great patient care and clinical programs. Do not value their staff in spite of mission statement.
pros: Lots of opportunities but very chaotic and at times toxic environments. A lot of cultural challenges.
cons: Toxic atmosphere, employees are not valued, training offered but never executed. Don't attempt to take FMLA or they'll fire you for "substandard performance" or some such nonsense.

pros: Great co workers.  Challenging work. Autonomy.  The opportunity to learn and grow every day.  The pay. The cafeteria is handy (too handy) and the food is pretty good
cons: Poor paid time off.  Parking is atrocious. Parking off site and being shuttled is mandatory.   On site parking available only to long term employees e.g. 25 years or longer

review_title: Excellent Place, Excellent People, Excellent Work
pros: Great opportunity to really make a difference in people's lives and in supporting the health of the state. Multidisciplinary collaboration is evident and each individaul has the opportunity to contribute to bettering care at the institution.
cons: Fast paced environment that really requires the ability to be flexible and remain calm under pressure. This is very hard work in a rapidly changing industry.

pros: The hospital makes every attempt to be patient and family centered. Staff consistenly work to make the patient experience the best it could possibly be. Very collaborative.
cons: To acquire and retain the best managers and directors the hospital needs to compensate them adequately. Salaries for these people are dismal, they are the glue of the organization.  The organization is top heavy with Vice Presidents.

review_title: Working for Maine Medical Center has been wonderful
pros: Great benefit/compensation package with flexible working schedules and empowered employees.  Very customer oriented, but internal and external
cons: Not terribly cost conscious and areas of responsibility are silo'd.  Seems like money is wasted on frivolous things while items that would improve productivity, but expensive are put off.

pros: Saving lives is always a great motivation to come to work. A strong team environment.
cons:
Only two weeks vacation 
No parking in garage for nursing unless nights or weekends

pros: The health insurance benefit plans are good.  There is a wow program with cash benefits if you pass the tests.
cons: This department has changed drastically and is run by bullies. You are only there to fill a seat they could care less for you as a human being. They have lost a great number of valuable long term employees

pros: decent medical benefits, good pay (if fought for at time of hire), nice 403b with match,
cons: work life balance can prove difficult with on-call schedule, adding on new facilities sometimes multiples in a year is just expanding too quickly with little standardization of systems/processes

job_title: Lead In Environmental Services in Portland, ME
pros: Good benefits. 403B match, good medical/dental that you pay based on what you make, room to advance in your job, tuition assistance, shift differentials, premium pay if the call you in or ask you to stay late, management stands up for you if you are in the right.
cons: I feel like pay could be a little bit more for how much the company makes but they do offer raises

job_title: IT Tech Training Analyst in Westbrook, ME
pros: Challenging, learning opportunities, flexible schedule, advancement opportunities
cons: Can be disorganized in relating to due dates. No regard for stress caused by piling up major releases. Others in department held to different standards. Need better work-life balance. Need ability to work from home permanently.

pros: Decent Salary, good manager, great co-workers.
cons: Poor senior management, IT division has limited understanding of technology, and no formal strategic or tactical planning.

review_title: IT is swirling the drain at MMC,  I'd stay away if you have a choice
pros: Worked with some very talented and intelligent people.
cons:
MMC is suffering from pervasive cultural issues that the ego-driven leadership either choose to ignore entirely or try to solve by adding more poorly executed technology to the environment. 
From a technology perspective, you won't realize just how far behind they are unless you come from an organization that embraces more current technology. You won't realize how far behind you have fallen until you decide to leave. The sad part is that leadership has no interest in closing that gap because they live in complete fear of change even though they won't admit it. If you are looking for a role that supports your desire to stay current MMC is the wrong place for you.
They spend a great deal of effort marketing their "core values" which look great on paper but are not practiced widely, particularly in IT where some teams are allowed to disregard them entirely with no repercussions.
Lastly, Information Security has managed to position themselves so that they have no checks and balances in place governing their operation, and they frequently behave in a punitive manner when questioned by anyone including the Senior leadership. This situation has impacted operations and patent safety immensely due to the resulting disruptions due to rushed deployments and the increasing amount of technical debt they are creating for the other teams to manage.  Leadership sits by silently and allows this to continue because they've all been told what happens if they don't.

review_title: Depends on department, shift and experience of management
pros:
Dedicated employees
Pay scale 
Great support staff
cons:
Difficulty parking
Cost of Benefits for a Family
Huge differences between dept's-some give lots of autonomy, others micromanage
Too busy to work on career goals
Don't know senior manager or Rich Peterson

pros: Good team work among certain role of employees.  Working to make employees feel valued and a genuine effort to bridge the communication gap between employee roles.
cons: Constantly changing priorities making challenging to get anything done.  Certain departments provide no upward growth if for support personal.

pros: Great clinicians! But they are leaving for less headaches and better pay. Best pediatric intensivist, but they will burn him out.
cons: Disconnected leadership with no vision. Leader ship is not good.The administration views you has expendable. most of them will retire in the next 5 years. Short cited decisions.

review_title: Interesting sometimes frustrating but allows me to do my best.
pros: High professionalism, stable workforce, teaching is stimulating. Some scheduling flexibility. Good documentation tho EMR is outmoded. The only game in town at moment
cons: Institution nearing end of product life. Stability leads to lack of culture change so feels like time warp. Only game in town at moment.

pros: Great nursing and ancillary support.
cons: Sometimes leadership seems out of touch with reality wanting folks to do more with less, closing units (and then not having beds available when needed!)

pros:
- Lots of variance in the work, projects very different from one to another
- Opportunities to develop and grow your career 
- Invest a lot in Daily Management
cons: - Like any large organization, there is a lot of "politics" that can be frustrating in project work.

review_title: Great place for experience and excellence in nursing.
pros:
Easy to move around between apartments. Always opportunities for change or advancement. 
Gain a lot of experience in a variety of medical specialties.
Hospital has obtained Magnet Status.
cons: Very Large organization with lots of upper management that doesn't always communicate needs.

review_title: Great company with a great mission.
pros: Great research environment. Senior scientific investigators are motivated, curious and open to training new scientists.
cons: Small research institute with limited resources  so job opportunities are not always available and professional advancement isn't always achievable in house.

review_title: MMC - Don't Come Here If You're Inventive
pros: It's in Maine and it can pay well.
cons: Top down management style, very hierarchical, little if any recognition that ideas could originate at the bottom.

pros: One reason I works here was because they have really good people working their and there all respectful and that encouraged me to work their
cons: There really isn't anything bad about working their

pros: Large Academic center. With  bit of a small town feel. Lots of clinical opportunities. Financially stable. Strong and supportive leadership. Great colleagues!
cons: A bit of a big machine at times and it is easy for things to get lost in the shuffle.

pros: one of the largest employers in the state, they pay competitive wages with solid benefits
cons: at least in my department, there's such a strong 'joining' atmosphere that you can feel isolated or less than if you don't participate in the activities or aren't super outgoing

pros: Consistent job where you're not asked to do too much, good benefits and very clear work

job_title: Cardiovascular Anesthia Tech in Portland, ME
pros: The people Iwork with are the best of the best. Quality care is given to the sickest
cons: We aren't paid enough for the responsibilty we have

pros: Benefits and compensation were okay. Most coworkers were okay to work with.
cons: Management doesn't care. Extreme harm to patients ranging from patients that need emergency surgery completely forgotten about to having candy in surgical instrument trays. Management lies as if it changes things and claps themselves on the back but actually makes worse changes and makes employees not care about the job thus making it more harmful for patients who need surgery.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Portland, ME
pros: Up to date with current research for best practices in  patient care. Conference funding for nurses to attend. Collabortive team meetings to share expertise in difficult patient care situations. Teamwork was on spot and helpful.
cons: Downsizing of employees to stay within budget.

review_title: Perfect Way to Get Your Foot in the Door
pros: Working as a technician is a great way to gain pharmacy experience in a hospital setting and for networking purposes. The full-time benefits are amazing!
cons: Stress can be a big factor when working in a pharmacy.

The only academic biomedical research facility in Southern Maine
SOME PIs are good. The 3-5 PIs that actually do have funding, actually does good research
cons:
People go in late and leave really early. Some people work 10-3
Spouses working together. Some even in the same lab . 
Maybe 2-3 labs actually has funding. The rest are inactive labs. 
Management doesn't really do much to help unhappy workers.

pros: Great benefits, Good atmosphere, great staff.

pros: Very much have enjoyed my time here.  It'll be sad to leave.
